content: This contribution hasn’t received enough positive votes from the community. The "FASTEST" option has therefore been deactivated.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Looks good.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: It is good.
good one
Can N be equal to 0? What about P? For clarity, it is better to add restrictions on the variables (lower and upper limit).

@clasheurDu44 you should check your solution. This formula doesn't work on p much more than n:

minimum = math.ceil((n*2)/p)*15

Example:
n=10
p=100

You result: 1:30
Correct: 3:00
Test 2 implies that the 3rd steak is cooking on both sides using both cooking plates at the same time.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Fun and challenging exercise.
I hope you received enough feedback from the community to improve your contribution. Once you have made the necessary updates, publish your contribution!
good one, not hard to understand
great question
It's a fun one

1) I think only the minimum time is interesting.
2) According to your tests, the output format must be [M]M:SS (no leading zero for minutes)

I didn't understand what means "1:30 per side" at first but reading "what is the minimum and maximum time" helped me understand it was time, and then I saw the output format, and I'm assuming it's minutes, and seconds. I think it's not very clear, but you can understand it within the context.

Also, it's not pretty clear that you should just use one cooking plate to cook it for the "maximum time" because it feels like that's not even solving a problem

Nevertheless, I think the problem overall could be enjoyable, and understandable enough like to play it
Nice problem I like it ! Keep going !
It's a fun one, I like it ^^

Simple and clear : very nice.
I liked the idea of min and max cooking time, but it seems just to easy to get max, compared to min.
The output presentation adds a nice twist.
For increased difficulty (or maybe another problem), why not add several degrees of doneness ?
for instance :
line 1 : the number R of rare steaks. (say 30 sec each side)
line 2 : the number M of medium steaks. (say 1:30 for each side)
line 3 : the number P of cooking plates.
This adds some multithreading flavor to the problem.

The problem is good but i don't understand how is it necessary to have maximum cooking time in output. It depends only on the constraint the there is at least one steak cooking so it's basically a simple multiplication. Moreover this is not specified that we have at least one cooking plate.
A simple, but interesting problem

You make the tacit assumption that a steak can be cooked one side, put into a buffer while another steak is cooking and put back on a plate later on.
That is of mathematical/combinatorial interest, but would not correspond to the procedure in the real world. Therefore I think this example is too simplistic.

Also the assumption that 24 steaks can be put, returned and removed on/from 24 plates in zero time is surprising.

To be more realistic:
 - only fully cooked steaks should go off the plate
 - a time to switch from one plate to the next should be counted.
The idea to have different times for each side goes a bit into the direction of the latter.

As such, the exercise is too simplistic or unrealistic in my opinion.

I dont understand the interest of calculating max and min cooking time, only min time should suffice.

And I agree with the idea to put the baking time in an input variable.
Maybe you could add the baking of the steaks, like you can cook a side just for 00:30 for a first test and it could be 1:15 for another test.

n=int(input())
p=int(input())
m=[-(-n*2//p)*1.5,3][p>n]
print(f'{int(m)}'+[":00",":30"][m%1==.5])
print(f'{n*3}'+":00")
I don't really see the interest in adding the maximum time, though. 

Also, having only 1'30 might be a bad design idea, as it limits the timer to either :30 or :00. 

Why not have it take 1:50? 

Maybe the problem would become too hard, but it might be interesting to have burgers taking 1:20 on one side and 0:40 on the other?
Please change Test 3 or Validator 3 so that they become different. Thanks.

it's true that changing the time could complicate the problem a bit.

I really like the idea of doing a different cooking time for each side!
I'll think about it.

Check it. If you have 3 steaks (1, 2, 3) with two side (a, b) each:

1) 1a 2a
2) 1b 3a
3) 2b 3b
Yes, you're right, well spotted

This makes no sense - you only have 2 cooking plates.
Plates 1 & 2 are busy for 3 minutes while steaks 1 & 2 are fully cooking at the same time.
Once a plate is free you still need 3 minutes to fully cook the 3rd steak.
So the answer should be 6:00
Agree, for me also seems odd, that 3rd stake will be cooked on both plates, of course if you have a grill maybe it is an option.
Check my example. Cooking order not defined. So I can stop cooking second steak (after cooked one side) and finish second steak on third iteration with third steak.

The issue with the example is you cannot remove any steaks until both sides are cooked, which is why the cook time should be 6:00 rather than 4:30. This may have been a miscalculation by the creator too, but I can understand what the example means.

Now I understand how it works after analyzing it more, what it means in theory is that a steak does take two plates, as in order to cook both sides. Now realistically, I don't understand how it works, but it makes sense to halve the time if you can cook both sides simultaneously. In order for this to work, p/2 would need to be equal to or greater than n.

Here is an example of what I mean ( where p# is the plate number, s# is steak number, and l equals steak side.)

00:00
p1-s1 p2-s2

01:30
P1-s1 p2-s2

03:00 (Both s1 and s2 are done)
p1-s3 p2-s3

04:30 (s3 is done)

> steaks until both sides are cooked

Where does this condition come from? I see `it cannot be removed until its side is cooked`. So I can cook one side of steak and remove them and continue to cook second side in future.
Never mind I misread it too, I assumed it was both sides but you're right it's only the side that's cooking on the plate lol
